Authors: Pablo Garcia-Murillo, Norio Tanaka, Pieter B. Pelser
Title:
Phylogeny and biogeography of Zannichellia and allied genera
(Potamogetonaceae), inferred from plastid and nuclear ITS DNA
sequences.
Abstract:
Zannichellia is a submerged aquatic genus found in Worldâs
fresh and /brackish water bodies. A morphology-based revision indicates
the center of the species diversity in Europe, including the
Mediterranean, yet the taxonomy has not yet been further studied. The
genusâ three allied genera, Althenia from the Mediterranean, Lepilaena
from Australasia (Australia and New Zealand), and Pseudlathenia from
South Africa, all of which have similar habitat preferences, have been
poorly surveyed, so that a little is known about the inter-generic
relationships. The enigmatic biogeographic relationships among the
genera were uninvestigated. We performed the first molecular
phylogenetic and biogeographic analyses of Zannichellia and two allied
genera, Althenia and Lepilaena, using combined plastid and nuclear ITS
DNA sequences. The resulting tree revealed a robust clade with Althenia
and Lepilaena, which was placed in a sister position relative to
Zannichellia. In the former clade, two out of three Lepilaena species
were clustered with one out of two Althenia species from the
Mediterranean. Hence, here we propose a uniting of Althenia and
Lepilaena into Althenia, consisting of Australasian and Mediterranean
species. In Zannichellia, a previously proposed infra-generic
classification was supported. The biogeographic analysis indicated two
trans-ocean dispersal events between Australasia and Europe, a novel
dispersal pattern, once in early Miocene (ambiguous origin) and the
other in late Miocene from Australasia. This dispersal pattern may be
occurred via South Africa in case if the other related genus,
Pseudalthenia, is included at some points of the evolution of
Zannichellia and allied genera.
